FOR STARTERS  You might think it's easy to calculate 50 % and 10%. Because it is.  50 % is the half (the half of 12 is 6, so 50 % of 12 is 6, just take the number and cut it in half!). You should never have any problems finding out what 50 % is.  10 % is literally a tenth, or easier: it is the decimal point one step to the left (10 % of 50.0 is 5.00, so it's 5!) What's 10 % of 36? It 3.6! That's even easier than 50 %! You should also never have any problems with 10 %!  But now what is 1 % of 36? It's 0.36 (shift the decimal point TWO steps to the left). Also, easy.  So 50 %, 10% and 1 % are a piece of cake. From now on I want you to never have any problems calculating that in your head anymore! And if you think about it, stuff like 5 % (a tenth of the half) or 25 % (the half of the half) are typically just as simple. Imagine 25 % of 700: Well, you halve it (350) and halve it again (175), and voilá, there you are, 25 % of 700 is 175. What's 5 % of 700 though? Again, you halve it to reach 350, and then you shift the decimal point one step to get to 35. 5 % of 700 is 35. (You can do it the other way as well if that's easier for you, first shifting the decimal point to reach 10 %, then halving it to reach 5 %. Find your way!)  If you understand those simple tasks, you may want to try to understand more complex numbers, because unfortunately most percentages are not that easy.  So that's an easy all-day way for other calculations: 80 % of 20. Okay, make it 10 %, and you know how, just shift the decimal point, 10 % of 20.0 is 2.00. So 10 % is 2. You want 80 %, so just multiply with 8 (because 10 % times 8 is 80 %), 2 times 8 is 16. 80 % of 20 is 16.  60% of 30, again make it 10 % (which would be 3). Now multiply that by 6 (3 times 6 is 18). So 60 % of 30 is 18.  Now you should not just be able to calculate 1 %, 5 %, 10 %, 25 % and 50 %, but also 20 %, 30 %, 40 % and so on! And you guessed it, you can do the same with 2 %, 3 % and the likes: What's 7 % of 90? Make it 1 % (shift the decimal place TWO places) to reach 0.9, then multiply by 7 to reach... well, how do you do that? 9 times 7 is 63, so 0.9 times 7 is 6.3: 7 % of 90 is 6.3, and you can calculate that in your head, I know it.  FOR PROS  When having odd numbers, just approximate them. 27 % of 166? 27 is around 25, which is an easy number to calculate with. It is a quarter. Just quarter 166, or easier cut it in half twice. 166 is also too difficult? Make it 160! 160 quartered is 40 (160 cut in half, 80, again cut in half, 40). So 25 % of 160 is 40, and 27% of 166 should be aroooound 40 as well.  Is that accurate? Well, close enough, 27 % of 166 is actually 44.82. 40 is a good approximation, and if it's in everday use it's close enough, if it's about finances you should obviously be more accurate. But if it's about money you'll use a calculator anyway.  Nother example, 12 % of 628. Okay, 12 % is close to 10%. 628 is close to 630. 10 % of 630 is 63. 12% of 628 should be somewhat close to 63. (It actually is 75.36). It's not extremely close but you are in the right scale. With approximations you're getting a grasp on percentages. You won't always be very close, but you can be relatively close WITHOUT USING A CALCULATOR.  A small advice: It is better to approximate the number instead of the percentage. If accuracy is important, keep it 12 % instead of 10 %, even if 12 % is odd and impractical, because the difference of two small percentage points can be quite high. You know how to calculate 10 % (just a tenth, duh), and you know how to calculate 2 % (it's 1 % times two), so why don't just add them together? It's understandable if you can't do that easily without using pen and paper, but maybe you can. 10 % of 630 is 63, 1 % of 630 is 6.3 (let's round that to 6 because we do it in our heads), 6 times 2 is 12 so 2 % is 12. That means 12 % is 63 plus 12, and that 75... 12 % of 630 is around 75 (actually it's 75.6) and that's strikingly accurate, as we know that 12 % of 628 is 75.36.  So you do have some liberty approximating the base number (you changed 628 to 630), but should try to avoid approximating the percentages (even a slight adjustment from 12 % to 10 % changes the result dramatically).  By the way, what if you approximated the 628 to 600? 10 % of 600 is 60, 1 % is 6, 6 times 2 is 12, 60 plus 12 is 72. So 12 % of 600 is 72. That is astonishingly close to 75.36.  FOR CHEATERS  And if you DO have a calculator at hand (and you should use it if it's about money or other very very important things):  [original number] divided by [100] multiplied by [percentage number]. Easy as that. 12 % of 168 dollars? 168 divided by 100 (now you know what 1 % of 168 is) multiplied by 12 (because you want 1 % exactly 12 times). It's 20 dollars and something. A ratio is a comparison between two numbers, it is another way of representing a fraction. For example, if there are 15 apples and 3 pears at a stall, then there are 5 times as many apples are there are pears (because 3 x 5 = 15), so we can say that, "for each pear, there are 5 apples at the stall", or that the ratio of pears to apples at the stall is 1 to 5 (written 1:5). Another way of expressing this is by saying that the number of pears divided by the number of apples is 3/15 = 1/5. In this way, fractions, decimal numbers, percentages, and ratios are all different ways of representing division operations. I hope this helps!

Simplifying fractions involves dividing both the numerator and denominator by their shared GCD to obtain the simplest form.  In the examples you mentioned, the instructor divided by 20 when expressing 80% as a fraction and by 50 when expressing 50% as a fraction. Although it may seem arbitrary, it was actually an intentional step to find the GCD of the numerator and denominator.  By reducing the fraction, the instructor was essentially finding the largest positive integer that divides both the numerator and denominator without leaving a remainder. This process, referred to as finding the GCD, helps obtain the simplest form of the fraction.  While the instructor didn't explicitly mention the term 'Greatest Common Divisor' (GCD), their intention was to simplify the fractions by dividing by their shared GCD. It would have been helpful if they had explicitly explained this concept, as it can be a key aspect of understanding fraction simplification.  I hope this clarifies the reasoning behind dividing by those specific numbers and sheds some light on the connection between simplifying fractions and finding the GCD. for 50% of 12, 50% is 50/100, which can be redued to 5/10 or 1/2. Then it's an easy matter of dividing 12 by 2 to get 6. (or, I suppose the proper operation would be 1/2 times 12/1 equals 6).  A similar process can be used for the other three operations. It may be easier if you convert each percentage to x/100, where "x" is the percentage being used, and then using the reductions mentioned in the video where applicable to get a simpler and easier to understand fraction. FOr instance, with the bottom left operation, "80% of 20", you could convert 80% to 80/100. Then, like Dave does at 1:48 or so in the video, divide the fraction by 20 to get 4/5. You then multiply that by 20 which would get you 80/5, which reduces to 16. (if you're wondering how that works, Dave should go over this in a much later video, but the gist is that any whole number-1 or 4 or 20 or 35167- are implied to be over 1; 1/1, 4/1, 20/1, and so on. The top numbers in the operation 4/5 times 20, 4 and 20, are multiplied and the bottom numbers, 5 and 1, are multiplied as well, thus 80/5.)  A potentially easier way (albeit imo slightly longer as far as the mental steps to take) lies with the top right operation. 10% (or 1/10th) of 50 is 5; it's essentially asking what 50/10 is. what you could do is figure out what 10% of any of those numbers are, and then multiply that number by whatever amount it takes to get to the percentage asked for. In the case of 80% of 20, you would ask what 10% of 20 is (20 /10), which is 2. You would then multiply that by 8-because 10 times 8 is 80 and the question is asking for 80%- to get your answer, which is 16. Same with the bottom right. 10% of 30 is 3 (or 30/10) , so we multiply 3 by 6 (6 times 10 is 60) which gets us 18. I hope that helps.
